column1: Will China’s energy crisis dampen its effort to cut emissions?
column3: China will play a key role in whether the world can curb global warming. But recent power shortages reveal challenges ahead.

column1: In Texas abortion cases, hints of new Supreme Court transparency
column3: As it wades deeper into what’s poised to be a scrutinized term, the Supreme Court appears to be more responsive to a call for greater transparency.

column1: ‘He poked mama bear’: Education clashes shape Virginia governor’s race
column3: Parental concerns over school closures and curriculum changes are making Virginia’s suburbs – which had been shifting Democratic – newly competitive.

column1: Merkel’s exit message for the world
column3: As she ends 16 years as chancellor, she worries most about losing history’s lessons about “acting in a purely national way.”

column1: Boston mayoral race brings Arab American identity into focus
column3: Annissa Essaibi George will face off against Michelle Wu on Tuesday in Boston’s mayoral elections. Ms. Essaibi’s campaign has highlighted the challenges of Arab Americans who struggle with racial definition in the United States.

column1: After Facebook Papers, how will Congress regulate social media?
column3: U.S. lawmakers on both sides of the aisle agree social media, especially Facebook, needs regulating. While steps like breaking up Big Tech are still on the table, new bills include more incremental protections – from an ‘erase button’ to a new digital ‘bill of rights’ for minors.

column1: This East St. Louis grocer tends an oasis of uplift in a food desert
column3: An East St. Louis corner store is a lifeline for residents who have to travel far to a supermarket for food. It’s also a hive of social connection.

column1: Supreme Court hearing on gun permit case could boost gun rights
column3: The U.S. Supreme Court plans to hear a case on a New York gun permit law on Wednesday that could expand the eligibility to carry firearms in public. The court last issued major gun rights decisions a decade ago, supporting the right to keep a gun at home for self-defense.

column1: As COP26 opens in Glasgow, world leaders are feeling the heat
column3: The U.N. climate summit in Glasgow, opening today, brings together leaders from around the world to lay out a vision for addressing the common challenge of global warming. Opening remarks likened the current climate situation to a “ticking doomsday device.”

column1: Promises of a shorter workweek: Could it be a win-win?
column3: As Americans quit jobs at a record pace, we look at the advantages of spending less time at work and how thinkers from Keynes to Nixon predicted it.

column1: For ‘love of the game,’ athletes can be mentally resilient
column3: As more athletes reveal their mental health challenges, some find aid in rediscovering a sport’s purpose.

column1: In 'historic action,' Biden pledges 30% methane reduction
column3: Methane is a highly potent pollutant responsible for a third of current warming from human activities. On Tuesday, U.S. President Joe Biden announced his COP26 plan to reduce methane emissions at a standard even stricter than under the Obama administration.

column1: Why Yahoo is discontinuing its platform in China
column3: Following the lead of other major tech companies, such as Microsoft and Google, Yahoo announced Tuesday that it would no longer offer its services in China. The departure comes as China’s government increasingly limits the data these companies can collect and store.

column1: At COP26, over 100 countries pledge to keep trees rooted
column3: Hailed as the first major step toward change in the U.N. climate conference, more than 100 nations pledged to end deforestation by the next decade. Trees are important for absorbing and storing carbon dioxide, serving as one of the world’s major carbon sinks.

column1: ‘We deserve to be represented’: Moms of color remake social media
column3: Parenting resources and the marketing surrounding them have mostly targeted white audiences. Now, women of color are breaking into the industry, taking to blogs and social media to create parenting communities that fill the gap – and brands are taking notice.

column1: ‘On the edge of a cliff’: What voting rights tell us about US democracy
column3: Basing his assessment of democracy in the United States on Black Americans’ right to vote, our commentator finds that ideal yet to be realized.

column1: Ways to weave a safety net: Free college and alternative justice
column3: Progress roundup: Young adults aging out of foster care and repeat offenders needing treatment are two different groups targeted with more services.

column1: Saving the Amazon, one wood-carved spoon at a time
column3: In an Amazon village that was once a hub for illegal logging, residents learn new ways to make a living from the forest that reward conservation.

column1: For workers, labor shortage means new leverage, and higher pay
column3: As employers confront a labor shortage, working Americans have new leverage to bargain for pay, benefits, and flexibility.

column1: For workers, labor shortage means new leverage – and higher pay
column3: As employers confront a labor shortage, working Americans have new leverage to bargain for pay, benefits, and flexibility.

column1: Diwali: Why the Hindu Festival of Lights is spreading around the world
column3: Diwali has been celebrated in South Asia for 2,500 years. But in recent years, the Hindu Festival of Lights has resonated more broadly.

column1: Wu and Pureval mayoral wins boost Asian American political presence
column3: Boston and Cincinnati will for the first time in their histories have Asian American mayors at the helm. The wins, say analysts, show the growing power of the Asian American Pacific Islander voters and pave the way for a stronger pipeline into political office.

column1: ‘The Farmer’s Lawyer’ tells a David and Goliath legal story
column3: Sarah Vogel digs into the unlikely victory of the class action she brought on behalf of farmers in the 1980s in “The Farmer’s Lawyer.”

column1: Minneapolis voters choose to keep police but ‘reform must continue’
column3: In Minneapolis, a proposal to replace the city’s police department with a new agency was rejected by voters on Tuesday. The initiative came out of citywide discussions on police reform after the murder of George Floyd.

column1: Iran-backed faction threatens post-election turmoil in Iraq
column3: Unsubstantiated claims of voter fraud in Iraq’s most recent election have sown uncertainty and heightened divisions between political groups in the country. Finals results for the election, hailed by the U.S. and U.N. as the smoothest in years, have not been released.

column1: Climate summit: The key is momentum, even if progress is slow
column3: Even without a COP26 breakthrough, technological progress and shifting opinion on climate change have put the world on a path to lower-carbon energy.

column1: No time for anger over climate change
column3: A young inventor at the global climate summit inspires the crowd to see ingenuity in everyone.

column1: It’s bleak, bloody, and No. 1 on Netflix. How ‘Squid Game’ won the pandemic.
column3: What does the global popularity of the violent Netflix series “Squid Game” say about the current cultural zeitgeist?

column1: 'Troubled region': UN report emphasizes horrors of Ethiopia's war
column3: Ethiopia’s yearlong war has seen alleged atrocities from all combatants, says a U.N. report. Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, said the investigation revealed “disturbing suggestions of ethnically motivated violence.”

column1: ‘Nomadland’ director brings her vision to Marvel’s ‘Eternals’
column3: Chloé Zhao pivots from her indie roots to make a big-budget Marvel film, “Eternals.” Can she make these heroes soar?

column1: Democrats’ big problem: How to win without Trump to run against
column3: For the first time since 2016, Donald Trump was no longer at the center of things. And his relative absence seems to have helped Republicans – and hurt Democrats.

column1: ‘The Stolen Lady’ imagines how the ‘Mona Lisa’ came to France
column3: Leonardo da Vinci’s famed portrait might have been lost forever, twice. Novelist Laura Morelli conjures the world of the artist and his elusive subject.

column1: Much of Africa still lacks electricity. The carbon ethics are thorny.
column3: The moral trade-offs involved in curbing climate change look very different in a Senegal village with no electricity.

column1: Q&A with Steven V. Roberts, author of ‘Cokie: A Life Well Lived’
column3: Cokie Roberts’ husband of 53 years writes a moving tribute to the late National Public Radio and ABC News journalist.

column1: Supply chain delays mean walnuts may not make the holiday table
column3: In California, shipping delays are affecting not just imports but exports, too. Without a way to ship holiday crops such as almonds, walnuts, and pistachios, farmers are losing out on markets and profits from overseas.

column1: 'Not going to stop': How US Justice Department fights cybercrime
column3: Ransomware attacks, in which hackers lock and encrypt data then demand exorbitant sums of money for its release, have risen significantly in the past year. The U.S. Justice Department is committed to fighting back, using extraditions and monetary seizures.

column1: International Criminal Court to probe Venezuela for rights abuses
column3: In its first official probe of a Latin American nation, the International Criminal Court is looking into potential crimes against humanity committed by the Venezuelan government against protesters and political opponents.

column1: An election in Nicaragua that could further dim democracy
column3: Daniel Ortega runs for his fourth consecutive term as president of Nicaragua virtually uncontested, having imprisoned all his political rivals.

column1: Europe plans border tax on carbon. Will others join the club?
column3: The COP26 climate summit is about voluntary steps, not mandates and penalties. But Europe is poised to add some tough love on the side. Will it help?

column1: In Israel, Arab magnanimity toward another minority
column3: In an apparent gesture of empathy, the leader of an Arab party in the ruling Israeli coalition asks that money for his community be shared with the minority ultra-Orthodox community.

column1: Donors’ dilemma: How to help hungry Afghans ... not the Taliban
column3: A winter of hardship looming for Afghans poses a dilemma for aid donors leery of indirectly helping the Taliban. Some are seeking creative solutions.

column1: Democrats and Republicans vie to be ‘the party of parents’
column3: Parents are rethinking the role government plays in their children’s education and opportunities. Both parties are striving to tap into that.

column1: What more is there to say about Princess Diana? ‘Spencer’ offers a fable.
column3: Kristen Stewart delivers a fierce performance in “Spencer,” a film that intends to impart a more profound view of Princess Diana than a biopic could.

column1: Robots roll to the rescue amid surging demand for food delivery
column3: As restaurants struggle to find workers and delivery drivers, a number of companies have developed small robots capable of distributing food. How can these robots help the food industry, and how much will they change it?

column1: No refs, no games: Can people play nice?
column3: Referee shortages pose a challenge in youth sports, where declining civility is blamed for an exodus of officials. But some solutions are underway.

column1: Voting rights: Justice Department sues Texas over election law
column3: This summer, Democratic lawmakers fled Texas in an attempt to prevent the passage of Senate Bill 1, but to no avail. Now, the Biden administration is suing the state over the same bill in an effort to overturn new voting restrictions.

column1: Nobel-winning author believes youth will bring hope to Nigeria
column3: In a country rife with corruption and extremism, Wole Soyinka believes young people have the energy and dedication needed to bring change and progress to Nigeria.

column1: Africa’s urgency to end the Ethiopian war
column3: A moral lesson from the lack of intervention in the Rwanda genocide helps push the continent’s leaders to prevent atrocities in Ethiopia.

column1: Methane gets its due: Climate pledge puts focus on super pollutants
column3: World leaders are turning their attention to super pollutants – the most potent greenhouse gases – in the latest efforts to slow global warming.

column1: Assassination attempt on Iraqi prime minister fails
column3: Seven of Iraq Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi's security guards were wounded in Sunday's attack at his home by at least two armed drones. The prime minister appeared only slightly injured.

column1: Why Biden's $1 trillion infrastructure bill finally passed
column3: The $1 trillion bill, which promises to create jobs and improve broadband, water supplies and other public works, was passed with votes from 13 Republicans Friday.

column1: Mandates, bully pulpits, and other presidential myths
column3: Presidents like to talk about mandates, but those can be something of a myth. Most of the time, it’s impossible to pin down why people vote the way they do.

column1: Here they go again: ABBA reuniting after 40 years
column3: The pandemic has acted like a Bat-Signal of sorts for ABBA, which returns with a new album, “Voyage,” at a time when fans say songs like the group’s are needed.

column1: Data on a warming planet: What’s at stake in global climate summit
column3: Do we really need to be hearing so much about climate change and a “COP26 meeting”? Here’s a chart-based briefing on why it matters.

column1: Safer venues? Investigation of Travis Scott concert begins
column3: Eight people died in a crush of fans at a Houston music festival Friday hosted by Travis Scott. The investigation has begun into how to keep concert goers safe.

column1: She tabled the discussion of a 'moot point'
column3: In the U.S., labeling something a 'moot point' means it's no longer worth discussing. In England, however, that means it's open to further debate.

column1: For me, the flower-child option arrived just in time
column3: My authentic self suffered through a home perm and much of high school, until I was rescued by the 1960s.

column1: From rainforest to row houses, honoring rights to home
column3: Progress roundup: Australia returns land to Indigenous residents, and in U.S. cities, aggregated data helps citizens curb urban blight and evictions.

column1: The gilded pages that brought light to the Dark Ages
column3: Medieval illuminated manuscripts reveal the vibrancy of early Christianity and the meticulousness behind their creation in “The Gilded Page.”

column1: ‘I had to stand up and say no’: Pro-choice Christians battle Texas law
column3: Faith featured prominently when Texas passed its controversial abortion law this year. But for some people of faith, it has inspired a newfound interest in, and activism around, reproductive rights.

column1: Could 3D printing help solve the housing crisis?
column3: 3D-printed construction is in its early stages. But potential benefits include speedier on-site construction, less waste, and reduced labor.

column1: Climate action by dictate? Or democracy?
column3: In India’s pledge for net-zero emissions, the world’s largest democracy faces off with the largest dictatorship, China, on which type of governance is best to curb carbon emissions.

column1: 'A struggle and a journey': Report shows US economy recovering
column3: The U.S. labor department’s recent report shows optimistic trends in unemployment rates and rising pay, which could help offset anticipated long-term inflation. Experts appear confident in the economy’s path to recovery.

column1: ‘I cannot wait’: Families reconnect as US travel ban lifts
column3: On Monday, vaccinated travelers from Mexico, Canada, and most of Europe will be allowed to enter the United States for the first time since March 2020. Families have long awaited the chance to reconnect with spouses and introduce babies born during the pandemic.

column1: As sea ice melts, will the Arctic become a different place?
column3: In the Arctic, ice sheets and glaciers are shrinking, wildfires have broken out, and even a region called the Last Ice Area shows unexpected melting. As the Arctic continues to warm, a summer without sea ice could spell out danger for countries around the world.

column1: Germany cuts carbon emissions. Not fast enough, young generation says.
column3: Germany envisions a green future, yet still burns lots of coal. Now a young generation wants to see goals matched by actions.

column1: How Belarus is using migrants to escalate conflict with EU
column3: Tensions are rising along the Belarus-Poland border as migrants attempt to cross into the European Union. Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has encouraged the border crossings, initially along the Lithuania and Latvia borders, say E.U. officials, as a destabilization tactic.

column1: Facebook whistleblower says metaverse adds more privacy concerns
column3: Facebook is coming under new scrutiny after unveiling its “metaverse” – which brings the internet to life in 3D. Whistleblower Frances Haugen warns that underlying concerns unveiled in the Facebook Papers about how the company operates remain unaddressed.

column1: Eyes on the driver: Biden wants a tech fix to curb drunk driving
column3: President Joe Biden’s infrastructure bill includes policies tackling auto safety. By 2026, all new vehicles will include systems to “passively monitor the performance of a driver ... to accurately identify whether that driver may be impaired.”

column1: Men are missing from college campuses: What’s being done to bring them back?
column3: A gender gap on college campuses has grown wider during the pandemic. Schools are responding with programs to support young men.

column1: Why COP26 stakes are so high for India’s women
column3: Women in rural India, facing hardship due to recent floods, exemplify the challenge of how to help the world’s poorest people adapt to climate change.

column1: How ballots can win over bullets
column3: Too many of today’s violent conflicts start with election disputes. The world is trying to ensure Libya’s first presidential election doesn’t go that way.

column1: Economics 101: More college classes bring moral debates to the surface
column3: Professors have often presented economics as the realm of rational people making efficient choices. Now many highlight underlying ethical debates.

column1: Climate crisis as change agent? For Israel and Jordan, a warmer peace.
column3: Israel-Jordan ties are thawing, and the climate crisis – and its focus on water and renewable energy – is giving the countries something to talk about.

column1: Inflation at 30-year high. Where it goes next is (partly) up to you.
column3: Here’s why the answer to today’s worrisome price spike may revolve around consumer and business mindsets, not just kinks in supply chains.

column1: On climate, a fraught Plan B: Carbon capture helps, but not enough
column3: At COP26, “nature-based” and engineered ways of capturing carbon have generated interest. But do they distract from what must be done on emissions?

column1: A light of truth on Nicaragua’s shady election
column3: A brave group of private poll watchers undercuts the regime’s legitimacy by exposing low voter turnout.

column1: Clinton and Penny’s ‘State of Terror’ catapults a powerful woman into risk-taking
column3: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Louise Penny’s “State of Terror” and Ken Follett’s “Never” imagine high-stakes situations where women take risks.

column1: Virginia’s wake-up call: Democrats ignore rural voters at their peril
column3: Accepted wisdom among Democrats has been that demographics – more voters of color and more young voters – would lead to victory. Last week’s defeat in Virginia shows the danger of complacency.

column1: Reading remedies: Schools assess pandemic’s effect on literacy
column3: Newsrooms across the country got together to report on the state of reading education – to share what classrooms look like today and what solutions are being tried to support struggling readers.

column1: Solution to divide-and-conquer strongmen: Unity
column3: From Turkey to Hungary to Brazil, opponents of populist strongman rulers are seeking to band together in electoral pacts to gain power.

column1: Louise Erdrich, Minnesota, and me
column3: Louise Erdrich’s “The Sentence” gave our essay writer insights into her Minneapolis hometown, offering a window into the protests for social justice.

column1: As prices surge, food banks face new hurdles to feed the hungry
column3: Food banks faced increased demand throughout the pandemic, and now they’re navigating surging food prices and supply chain bottlenecks. Bracing for the upcoming holidays, U.S. food banks worry they won’t have enough staples, like stuffing and cranberry sauce.

column1: In Hopi elections, language preservation is a core issue
column3: In the upcoming Hopi chairman elections, the role of language in tribal politics is front and center. The debate about whether the ability to speak and understand Hopi should be a prerequisite to running prompts bigger questions about culture, identity, and inclusion.

column1: Amid free press crackdown, Myanmar sentences US journalist
column3: On Friday, a Myanmar court sentenced American journalist Danny Fenster to 11 years in prison. The country’s military-installed government has forced media outlets to close, and an estimated 100 journalists have been arrested.

column1: F.W. de Klerk remembered for conflicted legacy in South Africa
column3: Former South African President F.W. de Klerk, who died Thursday, oversaw the end of apartheid rule with Nelson Mandela. Although he made significant contributions to end the nation’s minority white rule, Mr. de Klerk drew life-long criticisms as the last apartheid leader.

column1: In Mexico, locals invest in mangroves to help cool the planet
column3: Mangroves only grow on less than 1% of the Earth’s land, but experts agree they are critical to fighting climate change due to their ability to sequester large amounts of carbon. In places like Mexico, where mangroves continue to deteriorate, locals work to save them.

column1: A foodie delight, ‘Julia’ shows how one chef influenced America
column3: Few people on the planet were more interested in food than Julia Child, says the Monitor’s film critic. Judging from the documentary “Julia,” he adds, few people are as interesting.

column1: Is education a ‘right’? Case demanding civics classes tests theory.
column3: An educated society is vital to democracy, but are schools obligated to teach students how government works? And who decides, states or the courts?

column1: Britain forced Boris Johnson to U-turn on corruption. What happened?
column3: Britain has been rocked by a scandal over government anti-corruption rules. It is proving a gut check for democratic values.

column1: Why Albuquerque’s latest experiment in policing doesn’t involve officers
column3: Albuquerque, New Mexico, sends out mental health specialists to deal with nonviolent 911 calls, freeing up police to handle other emergencies.

column1: Is civics education a ‘right’? Rhode Island case tests theory.
column3: An educated society is vital to democracy, but are schools obligated to teach students how government works? And who decides, states or the courts?

column1: Russia changes its tune on climate change. What’s behind the shift?
column3: Russia seems to be getting serious about climate change. But the Kremlin’s shift in thought may need to go further to prepare for the future.

column1: Iraq steps up in the Belarus crisis
column3: A new Iraqi commitment to “migration governance” may lie behind its effort to end the trafficking and trauma of Iraqis used as pawns by a European dictator.

column1: Britney Spears' conservatorship ends. What's next for this tool?
column3: California Judge Brenda Penny terminated the conservatorship that controlled pop singer Britney Spears' life choices and money for nearly 14 years.

column1: Revival of a dynasty? Another Qaddafi seeks to lead Libya.
column3: Seif al-Islam, a son of late Libyan dictator Muammar Qaddafi, announced his candidacy for the country's presidential election next month.

column1: COP26 deal: Nations agree on phasing coal ‘down’ but not ‘out’
column3: Ahead of the COP26 talks in Glasgow, the United Nations set three criteria for success. None were achieved. But, said U.N. Sec.-Gen. Antonio Guterres, “we have some building blocks for progress.”

column1: Readers write: Do we need a Peace Corps anymore?
column3: Letters to the editor for the November 8, 2021 weekly magazine. Readers discuss early memories of race and their Peace Corps experience.

column1: Authors who made their mark with made-up words
column3: “Pandemonium,” “critical,” “assassinate,” and “eventful” all came from written literature before being widely adapted in spoken English.

column1: Riding with the wildlife rescuers: No creature too big, small, or wild
column3: When rescue facilities closed in Southern Arizona, Lisa Bates created her own wildlife animal hospital. Her Tucson Wildlife Center cares for 5,000 animals each year.

column1: COP26 scorecard: Summit leaves the heavy lifting for later
column3: The COP26 climate summit ended with less to show than organizers had hoped, but some governments and businesses launched their own green initiatives.

column1: All work, no play? Chinese millennials opt to ‘lie flat’ instead.
column3: Youths rebel against China’s ultracompetitive environment – with calls for people to “lie flat” and do the minimum – and Xi Jinping takes note.

column1: A win for clean governance in Europe
column3: A new anti-corruption party in the EU’s most corrupt nation, Bulgaria, leads in a parliamentary election, signaling a civic awakening.

column1: Are roads racist? Buttigieg says yes, talks transportation reform.
column3: All eyes are on Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg and how he will develop the transportation sector after the passing of President Biden’s infrastructure bill. Mr. Buttigieg says his plan includes building racial equity through highway design and road projects.

column1: ‘There’s always hope’: Myanmar frees jailed American journalist
column3: Danny Fenster, an American journalist who was sentenced by a Myanmar court to 11 years in prison, has been freed after six months through diplomatic negotiations. He is one of at least 126 journalists who have been detained since the military took power.

column1: International students return to US colleges as travel ramps up
column3: International students are returning to U.S. colleges, but the numbers are yet to make up for last year’s pandemic-induced decline. Colleges say international students bring diverse perspectives and are important sources of revenue for their schools.

column1: EU to sanction airlines facilitating migrant crisis in Belarus
column3: The European Union has extended sanctions to airlines, travel agents, and individuals believed to be helping migrants cross illegally into Europe. The migrant crisis is allegedly part of a “hybrid attack” being waged by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.

column1: Worker shortages: Is access to child care a key solution?
column3: Matching parents with child care is an idea that some groups serving the trades are using to woo women to their ranks. Could it work for other U.S. industries facing shortages as well?

column1: Can the US still build – and think – big? The Lowcountry may hold clues.
column3: On Monday, President Joe Biden signed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill designed to unlock supply chain capacity and bring jobs to places like Jasper County.

column1: When strangers become links in a chain of compassion
column3: When a stranger on the subway helped me recover my stolen lunch, I knew I had to pay it forward somehow.

column1: ‘America’s Librarian’ knows why people turn to libraries in times of need
column3: Nancy Pearl, possibly America’s best-known librarian and recommender of books, shares her thoughts on choosing what to read, and when to stop reading.

column1: Kitchen alchemy: Recipes to add to the repertoire
column3: Whether it’s holiday recipes or everyday meals, the season’s top cookbooks deliver flavor, a dollop of history, and rave reviews.

column1: Biden and Xi ‘meet’ and agree: US-China competition, not conflict
column3: Meeting virtually, Joe Biden and Xi Jinping did not resolve major disputes, but they did voice a commitment to responsible leadership. Is that enough?

column1: When climate change stops being policy and starts getting personal
column3: For many, climate change has remained a dry, policy-driven subject. But for Monitor correspondent Shafi Musaddique, it is a deeply personal matter.

column1: Frenemies: Why UK-French relationships survive their countries’ spats
column3: Political relationships are under strain between Britain and France. But the large French communities in the U.K. are managing the tension.

column1: What’s different for these Iran nuclear talks
column3: Water woes caused by climate change could compel Iran to seek a deal on its nuclear program – and join others in the Middle East in water cooperation.

column1: On freezing Poland-Belarus border, migrants cry for help
column3: Europe accuses Belarus of manipulating migrants trying to cross the Polish border. But the crisis highlights weaknesses in the EU’s refugee policy.

column1: Russian missile test pushes space junk swirling near astronauts
column3: On Monday, a Russian missile test endangered the astronauts aboard the International Space Station by targeting a satellite close by. With over 1,500 pieces of space junk now strewn about, the astronauts face a risk four times greater than normal.

column1: Defiant Bannon uses arrest as platform against Biden
column3: Steve Bannon faces criminal contempt charges from a federal court after defying a subpoena from Congress’ Jan. 6 committee. Mr. Bannon is one of several close allies to former President Donald Trump facing legal charges after the Capitol breach.

column1: Afghan Shiites turn to Taliban for protection as ISIS threat looms
column3: Many minority Shiites in Afghanistan aren’t convinced by the Taliban’s promises to protect them. But given the threat posed by the Islamic State, Taliban protection may be the closest thing to security.

column1: As Europe works to stay warm this winter, can Russia help?
column3: With Europe in a natural gas crunch, Russian President Vladimir Putin is touting the benefits of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which runs under the Baltic Sea and is awaiting German regulatory approval. Here’s a look at the supply shortage and how Russia factors in.

column1: Fearing authoritarianism, young Peruvians battle constitutional change
column3: Peruvian President Pedro Castillo wants to change the constitution. Critics fear he’s the next Latin American populist trying to consolidate power.

column1: In a step forward, China and US ease restrictions on journalists
column3: The U.S. and China reached an agreement this week to ease restrictions on foreign journalists. Experts say it’s a “hard-won achievement” – the result of more than a year of U.S.-China negotiations.

column1: Not 'friendly banter': Former English cricket star exposes racism
column3: Azeem Rafiq, a former national cricket player for England, gave emotional testimony Tuesday in parliament about the racist slurs he endured while on the team. An investigation was launched in September 2020 following Mr. Rafiq’s complaints of institutional racism.

column1: The tales trees tell – from history to climate change
column3: As COP26 made clear, action is needed to address climate change. But those actions must be well-informed, and tree rings can help with that.

column1: Why Africa’s bright spots catch US attention
column3: As the continent deals with coups, conflicts, and COVID-19, Niger is rising as a model for progress.

column1: Migrants in Belarus challenge Europeans to show their values
column3: The standoff between Belarus and the European Union over migrants illustrates the need for a coherent European immigration policy.

column1: 'Public face' of Jan. 6 riot sentenced to 41 months in prison
column3: Jacob Chansley was one of the first rioters inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6. On Wednesday, he was sentenced to 41 months in prison after pleading guilty to a felony charge of obstructing an official proceeding. “My behavior is indefensible,” he said.

column1: Paul Gosar, censure, and the further decline of civility in Congress
column3: Paul Gosar was censured Wednesday in what GOP leadership calls abuse of power. Democrats say Republicans, unlike in the past, refuse to rebuke their own.

column1: Where Rep. Pramila Jayapal got her spine
column3: Rep. Pramila Jayapal has been criticized for overplaying her hand, but colleagues say her style is consistent with a career driven by strong values.

column1: GOP chair: Under Trump, ‘we’ve become a working-class party’
column3: The head of the Republican National Committee joined the Monitor Breakfast to talk about the former president, the 2022 elections, and more.

column1: Oxford prepares for electric car future. Britons may be cool to the cost.
column3: Voters in the United Kingdom support a net-zero future. But when it comes to paying for electric car zones, their green enthusiasm changes.

column1: China meets its match in women’s tennis
column3: The Women’s Tennis Association defends a top Chinese player who disappeared after accusing a Communist Party leader of sexual assault.

column1: No 'great migration': Americans stayed put during pandemic
column3: Everyone knows the story: During COVID-19 lockdowns, hordes of Americans left dense urban centers for the countryside. The reality? While some did leave, mobility at large in the U.S. has been on a downward slide since 1985 – and the pandemic hasn’t changed that.

column1: As U.S. border policy remains murky, Mexico migrant camps swell
column3: Migrant camps on the U.S.-Mexico border are expecting a rise in population as the number of people attempting to get into the U.S. increases. City officials in Tijuana, Mexico, have attempted to control one camp by enclosing it within a chain link fence.

column1: Continental collaboration: North America summit makes a comeback
column3: For the first time since June 2016, the North America Leaders’ Summit between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico is taking place in Washington. The three national leaders will seek common ground on divisive issues from climate to migration and trade.

column1: Evacuations underway as floods drench British Columbia
column3: British Columbia declared a state of emergency on Wednesday as floods washed away roads, trapped hundreds of motorists, and engulfed farms. The military and air force are helping with evacuations, and the federal government has promised ongoing support.

column1: Letter from Colorado: Searching for bighorn sheep, finding patience
column3: After moving from New York City to the Mountain West, one Monitor reporter adjusts to a slower pace. Patience has its rewards ­­– especially outdoors.

column1: ‘The Correspondents’ portrays bold female reporters in World War II
column3: Judith Mackrell delves into the stories of six female reporters who, though they were banned from combat, covered some of the fiercest battles.

column1: Vigilance or vigilantism? Old laws’ legacy in modern US.
column3: The Rittenhouse trial, the trial of Ahmaud Arbery’s killers, and Texas’ abortion law all come amid more Americans demonstrating a willingness to police others’ behavior.
